case_vignette: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found in a confused state on an interstate rest area in Florida! She is unable to recall her name, address, or any other information regarding her person! She denies being the woman on a Connecticut driver's license found in her wallet! A telephone call with the police department of her hometown reveals that she had been reported missing three days ago by her husband! When the husband arrives, he reports that his wife has had a great deal of stress at work lately and before she went missing, was anxious to tell her boss that she will not meet the deadline for her current project! She has had two major depressive episodes within the past 4 years that were treated with citalopram! She drinks one to two beers daily and sometimes more on weekends! She does not use illicit drugs! Her vital signs are within normal limits! Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities! On mental status exam, she is oriented only to time and place but not to person! Short-term memory is intact; she does not recognize her husband or recall important events of her life!
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm feeling very confused and I can't remember my name, address, or any personal information about myself.
When did these symptoms start?
I'm not sure exactly when it started as I can't recall recent events clearly.
Have you experienced any recent head injuries or trauma?
No, I haven't experienced any recent head injuries or trauma.
Are you experiencing any other symptoms like headaches, dizziness, or changes in vision or hearing?
No, I am not experiencing headaches, dizziness, or changes in vision or hearing.
Do you have any history of neurological conditions or have you been diagnosed with any other medical conditions?
I have had two major depressive episodes in the past that were treated medically, but no other neurological conditions.
Are you currently taking any medications, including those for depression or any other conditions?
I have been treated with citalopram for my depressive episodes.
Do you have any family history of neurological disorders or dementia?
I'm not aware of any family history of neurological disorders or dementia.
Final Diagnosis: Dissociative Amnesia
